data.title: Set up a LibGDX project on a flash-drive or on GitHub with dependencies?
data.body:
Is there any way to setup an eclipse project on a flash drive or on GitHub that i can easily just import from any eclipse on any computer with dependencies already packaged so I don't have to download them again?

I can't find any documentation or tutorials on how to do this.

data.title: Added static method Input.Keys.isValidKeyCode(int)
data.body: Added static method Input.Keys.isValidKeyCode which can validate if keycodes are within [0,255], or whatever future range of valid keycodes.

data.title: Fix #3561
data.body:
Fix #3561 
Allows graphic card which supports GL_EXT_packed_depth_stencil to pack depth and stencil.

data.title: Fixes setPosition issue on NuPlayer (part 2)
data.body:
This is a follow up on the following PR

https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/3399

As it wasn't generating any activity for more than 3 months I've added a self contained project to make the testing easier than can be downloaded here:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7OWuDw42TLSQi1pQ0p0RXFSRVU/view?usp=sharing

The project is basically a simple music player with a play, pause, stop and a "play from second 30" buttons.

It includes a backend-android jar with the fix and it's easy to switch between default and the fix version from the android dependencies in the build.gradle file.

Issues will most probably appear on Nu Player devices where the "play from second 30" (that uses the setPosition() method) doesn't work after the first time. Just playing around, pausing, playing, playing from 30 and stopping the inconsistent behaviours should manifest on the non fixed version.

data.title: Shadow system 5 / 6
data.body:
Add classical shadow system!

This system supports point light.

Pass 1 : Compute depth maps.
Pass 2 : Accumulate light in shadow zones.
Main : Remove light accumulated during pass2.

data.title: Added Input.Keys.length to reflect the max integer value of keys
data.body: Added Input.Keys.length to reflect the max integer value of keys (currently 256). This is mainly to increase usability. In my use-case, I am trying to implement custom key-mapping, and I would like to simply use an array of size 256 to represent key alternatives.

data.title: Quaternion.getRollRad() returns an incorrect value in certain cases
Pass in the correct file for LwjglNative extraction fixes #3578
data.body: Passes in the correct `File` to be extracted.  It's fairly ugly.

data.title: Gdx class has static reference to Activity
data.body:
Hey guys, 
I see that onCreate and onResume of AndroidApplication https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/backends/gdx-backend-android/src/com/badlogic/gdx/backends/android/AndroidApplication.java#L164 the instance of current activity is saved as a static field in Gdx class. 

This would be causing a memory leak. I couldn't find any issues in issue tracker regarding this. 

Should we remove the reference in onDestroy/orPause ourselves?

data.title: Sprite vertex winding is not counter clockwise
data.body:
I just noticed that unlike [what the comment says](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/graphics/g2d/SpriteBatch.java#L253), the vertex winding is not counter clockwise. If you look at the code, you'll see that it starts at the bottom left (`fx, fy`), then to the top left (`fx, fy + height`) and then to the top right (`fx + width, fy + height`), and so on. This will cause everything to be culled when back face culling is enabled. It is easy to reproduce, in any of the tests enable backface culling:

``` java
Gdx.gl.glEnable(GL20.GL_CULL_FACE);
```

Either switching to frontface culling (`Gdx.gl.glCullFace(GL20.GL_FRONT);`) or switching to clockwise winding (`Gdx.gl.glFrontFace(GL20.GL_CW);`) will make it appear again.

I noticed this when using the vertices of the `Sprite` class (to benefit from `AtlasSprite`) as base for a 3d surface. So it is not only `SpriteBatch`.

Although easy to fix, I'm not sure what the impact of it would be.

data.title: "Deprecated Carbon Component Manager" on OS X El Capitan
data.body:
Hello! After updating to OS X El Capitan I'm seeing the following warning when launching LibGDX games:

"WARNING:  140: This application, or a library it uses, is using the deprecated Carbon Component Manager for hosting Audio Units. Support for this will be removed in a future release. Also, this makes the host incompatible with version 3 audio units. Please transition to the API's in AudioComponent.h."

This is an OpenAL-Soft issue, [which has already been fixed](https://github.com/kcat/openal-soft/issues/20). According to [this thread in LWJGL forums](http://forum.lwjgl.org/index.php?topic=5994.0), for updating LWJGL2 apps "it should just be matter of dropping the latest openal-soft natives (which you can grab them from the nightly builds of LWJGL3) over the old natives". But I'm not sure if that applies to LibGDX apps too. 

Notice that the current nightly build of LWJGL does not include the updated OpenAL-Soft library (yet.)

gdx-setup: updated libgdx-utils 3rd party extension
Reducing the size of the repo with BFG?
data.body: I know that the Git repo for libgdx is huge due to historical reasons (it used to have binaries included).  There's a tool for removing files from old commits, though, called [BFG](https://rtyley.github.io/bfg-repo-cleaner/).  It's supposed to be far easier to use than Git's built-in tools for cleaning up history.  Has anyone looked into that?

data.title: adds rotationChanged method for Actor class
data.body:
The actor class has an existing `positionChanged` method that can be overridden to check for position changes.  In addition, there's one for `sizeChanged`.  However, I noticed there was no option for rotation changes so I added it.

I apologize, I haven't actually been able to test these changes because of a Maven issue so if someone could review this that would be great.  In addition, this is my first pull request for libgdx (I have the CLA sent in already).

data.title: Red and Blue color values swapped on iOS app (RoboVM issue?)
data.body:
To begin, I am not sure if this is a LibGDX issue, a RoboVM issue, or an issue with my application configuration. 

I have a major roadblock in releasing my iOS app, which concerns the swapping of the red and blue color  bits on my app. I have tested my app on an Android device, on both an OS X and Windows machines, and on the iOS simulator. On all these devices, the color values appear like the screenshot below:

![correct](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9423063/11161959/86fc6316-8a41-11e5-92fd-3aa402da3ddf.png)

However, on an actual iOS device, the colors appear like the following image:

![incorrect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9423063/11161961/9c95c8de-8a41-11e5-81b0-59a9bd18c682.png)

I tested the app on multiple iOS devices running different versions of iOS (8 and 9), and it still appeared like the second, incorrect image. 

I tried to edit the color and depth formats in the IOSApplicationConfiguration to no avail, and tried all combination of the two. I also looked at the documentation for any pList attributes that may be causing the bug, but I found nothing of relevance. What could be a possible explanation to this error?

The project was first generated using the LibGDX Eclipse project generation utility back when LibGDX was still in version 1.5, and RoboVM was still in Beta. The projects have been converted to Gradle projects using the Eclipse Gradle plugin, and I am compiling the project using the Eclipse RoboVM plugin. Hopefully this information helps. I will provide code snippets of any part of my code if asked.

data.title: creating a FrameBuffer with stencil and depth attachments causes a crash on Linux/GeForce GTX 970
data.body:
This is a similar issue to https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/issues/3422

When creating a FrameBuffer with both depth and stencil buffers on my Linux desktop with a GeForce GTX 970, [line 183 of GLFrameBuffer](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/graphics/glutils/GLFrameBuffer.java#L183) returns GL_FRAMEBUFFER_UNSUPPORTED.

To test the validity of this, I modified [line 186](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/graphics/glutils/GLFrameBuffer.java#L186) to:

`&& (Gdx.graphics.supportsExtension("GL_OES_packed_depth_stencil") || Gdx.graphics.supportsExtension("GL_EXT_packed_depth_stencil"))) {`

The crash does not happen and the FrameBuffer is created when using the altered version of GLFrameBuffer.

I've tested the stencil buffer by running my stencil code inside of it and then rendering the FB texture with a SpriteBatch and received the same screen output as I do when not using the FB, so it seems to be a valid fix.
